binaryClass 1.0.0

Compare ROC Curves for Different Binary Classification Models

Source: R/compare_model_rocs.R
compare_model_rocs.Rd

This function fits multiple binary classification models (stepwise logistic regression, lasso, and ridge) to the same dataset and plots their ROC curves for comparison. It helps visualize the performance differences between models.

Usage

compare_model_rocs(
  formula,
  data,
  training_percent = 0.8,
  plot_title = "Comparison of ROC Curves",
  save_plot = FALSE,
  pdf_filename = "roc_curves_comparison.pdf"
)

Arguments

formula

An object of class \"formula\": a symbolic description of the model to be fitted (e.g., `response ~ predictor1 + predictor2` or `response ~ .`).

data

A data frame containing the variables in the model.

training_percent

A numeric value between 0 and 1 indicating the proportion of the data to use for training. Default is `0.8`.

plot_title

A character string for the plot title. Default is "Comparison of ROC Curves".

save_plot

Logical value indicating whether to save the plot to a PDF file. Default is FALSE.

pdf_filename

A character string specifying the name of the PDF file if save_plot is TRUE. Default is "roc_curves_comparison.pdf".

Value

A list containing the ROC objects for each model and their AUC values:

  • `stepwise_roc`: The ROC object for the stepwise logistic regression model.

  • `lasso_roc`: The ROC object for the lasso regression model.

  • `ridge_roc`: The ROC object for the ridge regression model.

  • `auc_values`: A named numeric vector of AUC values for each model.

  • `best_model`: The name of the model with the highest AUC.

Models Compared

This function compares the following three models:

  • Stepwise Logistic Regression: Full model with all predictors from formula

  • Lasso Regression: L1 regularization that can shrink coefficients to zero

  • Ridge Regression: L2 regularization that shrinks coefficients

Note that this is a simplified subset of models compared to OptimalModelSearch, which additionally includes backward stepwise, forward stepwise, and GAM models.

Relationship with OptimalModelSearch

While this function is a standalone tool, users can also generate ROC curves using:

  • OptimalModelSearch(formula, data, criterion="AUC", plot_roc=TRUE) to plot only the best model's ROC curve

  • OptimalModelSearch(formula, data, criterion="AUC", plot_roc=TRUE, plot_comparison=TRUE) to plot all models' ROC curves

  • plot_model_rocs(result) where result is the output from OptimalModelSearch with AUC criterion

The approaches differ in that compare_model_rocs only compares stepwise, lasso and ridge, while OptimalModelSearch compares full GLM, backward stepwise, forward stepwise, GAM, lasso, and ridge.

See also

OptimalModelSearch for more comprehensive model selection, plot_model_rocs for plotting ROC curves from OptimalModelSearch results

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Create a sample dataset
set.seed(123)
test_df <- data.frame(
  x1 = rnorm(100),
  x2 = rnorm(100),
  y = sample(c(0, 1), 100, replace = TRUE)
)

# Method 1: Compare ROC curves using compare_model_rocs
result <- compare_model_rocs(y ~ ., data = test_df)

# Access the ROC objects
result$stepwise_roc
result$lasso_roc
result$ridge_roc

# See the AUC values
result$auc_values

# Check which model performed best
result$best_model

# Method 2: Compare ROC curves using OptimalModelSearch (more models)
# Automatic ROC curve of the best model
oms_result <- OptimalModelSearch(formula=y ~ ., data=test_df,
                              criterion="AUC", plot_roc=TRUE)

# Automatic comparison of all models (full GLM, stepwise, GAM, lasso, ridge)
oms_result <- OptimalModelSearch(formula=y ~ ., data=test_df,
                              criterion="AUC", plot_roc=TRUE, 
                              plot_comparison=TRUE)
} # }
